title: Genealogy of Judah
shortSummary: 1 Chronicles Chapter 2 provides a detailed genealogy of the tribe of Judah, tracing the descendants from Judah himself through several generations, including notable figures such as David. This chapter establishes the lineage and tribal heritage essential for understanding Israel’s history and God's covenant promises through the tribe of Judah.
timeline: c. 1400-1000 BC - Period of the Israelite tribal settlements and early monarchy

keyCharacters.name: Judah
keyCharacters.description: One of the twelve sons of Israel, patriarch of the tribe of Judah, whose descendants include King David.

keyCharacters.name: Pharez
keyCharacters.description: Son of Judah and Tamar, ancestor of the royal line leading to David.

keyCharacters.name: Hezron
keyCharacters.description: Descendant of Pharez, a key figure in the genealogy of Judah's family.

keyCharacters.name: David
keyCharacters.description: The seventh son of Jesse, from the tribe of Judah, who became Israel’s greatest king.

definitions.definition: A woman from Canaan, the land inhabited by peoples whom God commanded Israel to displace; Tamar, Judah’s daughter-in-law, was a Canaanitess.
A phrase describing Achar (Achan), who sinned by taking accursed things, causing trouble and judgment upon Israel.
A woman who lives with a man but has lower status than his wife; Caleb’s concubines bore him children.
A leader or chief of a tribe or clan; Nahshon is called prince of the children of Judah.

outline.heading: The Sons of Israel and Judah’s Immediate Family
outline.description: The chapter opens with a listing of Israel’s twelve sons and then focuses on Judah’s sons and grandsons, highlighting the family’s beginnings and the birth of Pharez and Zerah through Tamar, emphasizing God’s providential preservation of the Messianic line.

outline.heading: Descendants of Hezron and the Line of David
outline.description: This section traces the descendants of Hezron, including Ram, Amminadab, Nahshon, Boaz, Obed, Jesse, and David, showing the royal lineage and God’s faithfulness in preserving the covenant line.

outline.heading: Caleb’s Family and Their Influence
outline.description: The genealogy expands to Caleb’s descendants, detailing his children, concubines, and the cities and clans associated with his family, illustrating the growth and settlement of Judah’s tribe.

outline.heading: Families and Clans of Judah
outline.description: The chapter concludes with listings of families, clans, and scribes dwelling in various towns, showing the organizational structure and heritage within Judah’s tribe.

application: Recognize God’s sovereign hand in preserving His covenant through imperfect people, encouraging trust in His plan despite human failures.
Value your spiritual heritage and family legacy, seeking to live in a way that honors God and blesses future generations.
Understand the importance of obedience to God’s commands to avoid becoming a 'troubler' like Achar, and repent quickly when sin is found.
Commit to faithfulness in your role within the church and community, just as the families and clans served specific functions in Israel.

keyVerses.text: Ozem the sixth, David the seventh:
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights David’s place in the lineage of Judah, underscoring his significance as God’s chosen king.

keyVerses.text: And Ram begat Amminadab; and Amminadab begat Nahshon, prince of the children of Judah;
keyVerses.significance: This verse introduces Nahshon as a leader, showing the establishment of leadership within Judah’s tribe.

keyVerses.text: And the sons of Carmi; Achar, the troubler of Israel, who transgressed in the thing accursed.
keyVerses.significance: This verse serves as a solemn reminder of the consequences of disobedience and sin within God’s people.
